Summary: The proposal aims to develop a hybrid probabilistic inference framework combining variational inference (VI) and Markov Chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) to address scalability and robustness challenges in deep learning. It proposes dynamic switching between VI and MCMC, structured approximations for scalability, and adaptive uncertainty quantification (UQ) techniques.
Strengths: Clear problem statement highlighting limitations of current probabilistic methods in deep learning.
Innovative idea of combining VI and MCMC to leverage their respective strengths.
Comprehensive experiment plan covering synthetic benchmarks, high-dimensional models, and real-world tasks.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed technical specifics on the dynamic switching mechanism and structured approximations.
Experiment plan could benefit from more detailed baselines and validation metrics.
Limited discussion on potential challenges and risks in implementing the proposed framework.
Questions: How will the dynamic switching mechanism between VI and MCMC be implemented technically?
What specific structured approximations will be used for neural networks, and how will they be optimized?
What are the expected computational overheads of the hybrid framework, and how will they be mitigated?
Limitations: Potential computational overhead from combining VI and MCMC.
Risk of approximation biases persisting despite the hybrid approach.
Challenges in scaling structured approximations to very high-dimensional spaces.
